title: How to Use KDSPY CORRECTLY for Niche Research

tactics.name: Proof of Concept
tactics.description: Identify niches with under 150 reviews and $500+ monthly revenue to ensure viability and lower competition.
steps: Search keywords related to your niche
Filter results by review count (≤150) and monthly revenue (> $500)
caveats: Exclude major publishers like Carson Delarusa
source_quotes: we want to be creating books where we're not up against main authority figures

tactics.name: kdspy-filtering
tactics.description: Use KD Spy to filter books with under 150 reviews and $500+ monthly revenue
steps: Highlight keywords from previous research list
Use KD Spy to filter books by review count and revenue
Mark valid results as 'yes' or 'no' in tracker
caveats: No results may indicate niche is saturated
source_quotes: we want four or five books with 150 reviews or less

tactics.name: Trademark Keyword Filter
tactics.description: Identify non-trademarked keywords by cross-referencing KD Spy results with USPTO trademark database
steps: Search KD Spy for keyword variations
Check USPTO trademark database for conflicts
caveats: Legal risks if trademarked terms are used
source_quotes: I spy monster trucks. And we're looking at where else are we here? Construction coloring book for children.

tactics.name: Sales Rank Filtering
tactics.description: Prioritize niches with low review counts and high sales rank potential
example_niches: big construction truck activity books for kids
source_quotes: Filter from the reviews 150 and below reviews.

tactics.name: remove_outliers
tactics.description: Eliminate books with extreme sales ranks to focus on competitive yet achievable niches
steps: Identify outliers with sales ranks significantly higher or lower than peers
caveats: Outliers may include low-quality books with poor covers or keyword misuse
source_quotes: "Get rid of any that are miles out from any of the others."

tactics.name: analyze_word_cloud
tactics.description: Extract high-performing keywords from top-selling books for title/subtitle optimization
steps: Generate word cloud from top niche books
caveats: Avoid keyword stuffing; ensure relevance to target audience
source_quotes: "This brings up different words that we can use for our analysis..."

heuristics.name: Review Threshold Boost
heuristics.condition: If median_reviews < 150, prioritize for lower competition
source_quotes: we're looking for four to five books to meet this criteria

heuristics.name: review-threshold-boost
source_quotes: we're looking for 150 reviews or less

heuristics.name: Low Review Boost
source_quotes: We've got from here upwards. So, no, it's one.

heuristics.name: low_review_boost
heuristics.condition: If median reviews are below 200, prioritize niches with potential for rapid growth
source_quotes: "Books here that have under 150 reviews that are earning some excellent revenue."

claims.statement: Niche viability can be validated by finding 4-5 books with <150 reviews and $500+ monthly revenue.
source_quotes: there are four. I've highlighted them right here
this means if we have proof of concept...

claims.statement: Traditional methods prioritize topics with <3,000 search results
source_quotes: the traditional method is to find topics that have less than 3,000 results

claims.statement: Average sales rank for coloring books is 244,000
Books with low review counts can achieve high revenue in niche markets
source_quotes: "There's no reason why you can't feature in these top books..."

niche_patterns.description: Target underserved niches with specific constraints to avoid major competitors
niche_patterns.why_it_works: Limits competition while maintaining profitability potential
source_quotes: we wouldn't count. Let's have a look at one
those books that have been around for years and years
